bestBHT.bht: Jesus and his disciples ventured to the region of Mount Hermon in Iturea, ruled by Herod Philip, granting Jesus safety and uninterrupted teaching. Positioned on the mountain slope, Jesus took advantage of this setting to provide his disciples with vital instruction on his forthcoming crucifixion. This was a pivotal moment for the disciples to reveal how much they had absorbed from their surroundings, as well as Jesus's direct teachings. Before this, Jesus took time alone to pray, setting the stage for the profound revelation that was to follow.

Henry Alford: With the exception of the introduction in Luke, which describes the Lord to have been alone praying, and joined by his disciples,—and the omission of the praise of and promise to Peter by both St. Mark and St. Luke, the three are in exact accordance.
On this latter omission no stress must therefore be laid as to the character of Mark's Gospel, as has been done.
The three are in exact accordance.
Philip Schaff: He had been ‘alone praying; ‘an important preparation for the important revelation which was to follow.
This was not necessarily ‘in the way ‘from Bethsaida to Cesarea Philippi, but may have been during some journey while in those regions.
Mark is less full than Matthew in Mark 8:28-30, but in exact accordance.
Archibald T. Robertson: This region is on a spur of Mount Hermon in Iturea ruled by Herod Philip so that Jesus is safe from annoyance by Herod Antipas or the Pharisees and Sadducees.
Up here on this mountain slope Jesus will have his best opportunity to give the disciples special teaching concerning the crucifixion just a little over six months ahead.
It was time that the disciples reveal how much they had been influenced by their environment as well as by the direct instruction of Jesus.
John Gill: And Jesus went out, and his disciples... into the towns Caesarea Philippi; and by the way he asked his disciples; saying unto them." (27 words)
For this Caesarea was rebuilt by him and called so in honour of Tiberius Caesar." (14 words)
He put this question in order to bring out their sense of, and faith in him." (17 words)

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus and his disciples find themselves in a region ruled by Herod Philip, away from the Pharisees and Sadducees who have been opposing him. They are on a mountain slope, providing a perfect opportunity for Jesus to impart special teaching about his upcoming crucifixion. It is a crucial moment for the disciples to reveal how much they have truly absorbed from their environment and the direct instruction of Jesus. In preparation for what is to come, Jesus takes time to pray alone. As they journey, Jesus asks his disciples a question, not necessarily on the way to Caesarea Philippi, but perhaps during their time in those regions. Although Mark is less detailed in his account compared to Matthew, their narratives are in exact accordance.

Jesus and his disciples find themselves in a region ruled by Herod Philip, away from the Pharisees and Sadducees who have been opposing him. They are on a mountain slope, providing a perfect opportunity for Jesus to impart special teaching about his upcoming crucifixion. It is a crucial moment for the disciples to reveal how much they have absorbed from their environment and Jesus's direct instruction. In preparation, Jesus takes time to pray alone. As they journey, Jesus asks his disciples a question, and though Mark is less detailed than Matthew, their narratives align.

Jesus and his disciples ventured to the region of Mount Hermon in Iturea, ruled by Herod Philip, granting Jesus safety and uninterrupted teaching. Positioned on the mountain slope, Jesus took advantage of this setting to provide his disciples with vital instruction on his forthcoming crucifixion. This was a pivotal moment for the disciples to reveal how much they had absorbed from their surroundings, as well as Jesus's direct teachings. Before this, Jesus took time alone to pray, setting the stage for the profound revelation that was to follow.

Jesus and his disciples found themselves in a region ruled by Herod Philip, away from the Pharisees and Sadducees who opposed Jesus. This mountainous area provided the perfect setting for Jesus to impart important teachings, specifically about his upcoming crucifixion. The disciples' response was crucial, as it revealed the extent to which they had been influenced by their surroundings and Jesus' instructions. Prior to this, Jesus had taken the time to pray alone, preparing himself for the revelation that would follow. Though Mark's account is less detailed, it aligns with the narratives of Matthew and Luke.

Jesus and his disciples, seeking refuge from the opposition of the Pharisees and Sadducees, found themselves in a region ruled by Herod Philip. As they stood on the mountain slope, Jesus saw this as an opportune moment to teach his disciples about his imminent crucifixion. Their reaction would reveal how much they had learned from both their environment and Jesus' direct instruction. Before this significant revelation, Jesus withdrew to pray alone, preparing himself for what was to come. Though Mark's account is less detailed, it aligns with the narratives of Matthew and Luke.
